articles.headline: Massachusetts Sues 5 Major Banks Over Foreclosure Practices
articles.snippet: Massachusetts is suing the nation’s five largest mortgage lenders, including Bank of America and JPMorgan Chase, over deceptive foreclosure practices.
articles.abstract: Massachusetts is suing the nation’s five largest mortgage lenders, including Bank of America and JPMorgan Chase, over deceptive foreclosure practices.
articles.lead_paragraph: Citing extensive abuses of troubled borrowers across Massachusetts, the state’s attorney general sued the nation’s five largest mortgage lenders on Thursday, seeking relief for consumers hurt by what she called unfair and deceptive business practices.

articles.headline: Time to Accelerate the Housing Recovery
articles.snippet: Many economists say the slow recovery in housing is inhibiting the nation’s economic rebound and that new steps must be taken to help homeowners.
articles.abstract: Many economists say the slow recovery in housing is inhibiting the nation’s economic rebound and that new steps must be taken to help homeowners.
articles.lead_paragraph: It’s housing, stupid. More precisely, it’s housing finance.

articles.headline: Ford Strives for Elegance in Lincoln Brand
articles.snippet: The automaker is striving to restore the luster to Lincoln, its luxury brand, which in recent years has been catering to older, less affluent consumers.
articles.abstract: The automaker is striving to restore the luster to Lincoln, its luxury brand, which in recent years has been catering to older, less affluent consumers.
articles.lead_paragraph: DEARBORN, Mich. — Every successful luxury car needs an identity for which consumers will pay a premium. Mercedes has its classic looks. Lexus epitomizes creature comforts. For BMW, performance is important.

articles.headline: For Jobless, Little Hope of Restoring Better Days
articles.snippet: A new study found that just 7 percent of those who lost jobs after the financial crisis have regained or exceeded their previous financial position, a new study found.
articles.abstract: A new study found that just 7 percent of those who lost jobs after the financial crisis have regained or exceeded their previous financial position, a new study found.
articles.lead_paragraph: People across the working spectrum suffered job losses in recent years: bricklayers and bookkeepers as well as workers in manufacturing and marketing.

articles.headline: Contractor’s Work Faulted at U.S. Pension Guarantor
articles.snippet: The Integrated Management Resources Group, which determined payments to retirees, was found to make many errors, but the company was not replaced even after the flaws were noticed.
articles.abstract: The Integrated Management Resources Group, which determined payments to retirees, was found to make many errors, but the company was not replaced even after the flaws were noticed.
articles.lead_paragraph: A small company with a big contract to determine how much the government pays people whose pension plans have failed got the numbers wrong, a new audit has found.

articles.headline: Democrats See an Advantage in Debate Over Payroll Tax
articles.snippet: Senate Democrats have put proud antitax Republicans in the position of opposing a tax cut for the middle-class because it comes with a surtax on higher earners.
articles.abstract: Senate Democrats have put proud antitax Republicans in the position of opposing a tax cut for the middle-class because it comes with a surtax on higher earners.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — After struggling all year for an economic message that resonates broadly with Americans in hard times, President Obama and Congressional Democrats have settled on one they believe can carry through next year’s election as they use a fight over payroll taxes to portray Republicans as defenders of the wealthy at the expense of the middle class.

articles.headline: For Afghan Woman, Justice Runs Into Unforgiving Wall of Custom
articles.snippet: A pardon for an Afghan woman who was imprisoned for adultery after she reported being raped came with the expectation that she would marry her attacker.
articles.abstract: A pardon for an Afghan woman who was imprisoned for adultery after she reported being raped came with the expectation that she would marry her attacker.
articles.lead_paragraph: KABUL, Afghanistan — When the Afghan government announced Thursday that it would pardon a woman who had been imprisoned for adultery after she reported that she had been raped, the decision seemed a clear victory for the many women here whose lives have been ground down by the Afghan justice system.

articles.headline: German Fears About Inflation Stall Bold Steps in Debt Crisis
articles.snippet: To German ears, bond purchases, or anything that smacks of printing money, sound like a recipe for skyrocketing prices.
articles.abstract: To German ears, bond purchases, or anything that smacks of printing money, sound like a recipe for skyrocketing prices.
articles.lead_paragraph: BERLIN — Norbert Schulze was not yet born when the hyperinflation of the 1920s deeply scarred the German psyche. But he still remembers the Reichsmark notes denominated in millions and billions that years later were tucked into a box with the family’s old black-and-white photographs.

articles.headline: Learning Too Late of the Perils in Gas Well Leases
articles.snippet: Americans have signed millions of leases allowing oil and gas companies to drill on their land, but some landowners are finding out the hard way what their contracts actually say.
articles.abstract: Americans have signed millions of leases allowing oil and gas companies to drill on their land, but some landowners are finding out the hard way what their contracts actually say.
articles.lead_paragraph: After Scott Ely and his father talked with salesmen from an energy company about signing the lease allowing gas drilling on their land in northeastern Pennsylvania, he said he felt certain it required the company to leave the property as good as new.
articles.byline: By Ian Urbina and Jo Craven McGinty

articles.headline: Republican Leaders Still Seem Torn About Romney
articles.snippet: Republicans, though bullish about their party’s chances of winning the White House, are coming to the conclusion that their nominee will carry substantial flaws into the general election.
articles.abstract: Republicans, though bullish about their party’s chances of winning the White House, are coming to the conclusion that their nominee will carry substantial flaws into the general election.
articles.lead_paragraph: ORLANDO, Fla. — Republican leaders remain bullish about their party’s chances of winning the White House, but after spending much of this year unsuccessfully trying to recruit new candidates, they are coming to the conclusion that their eventual nominee will carry substantial flaws into the general election.

articles.headline: Jobless Rate Dips to Lowest Level in More Than 2 Years
articles.snippet: In the midst of global economic turmoil, the American unemployment rate unexpectedly dropped last month to 8.6 percent, and the nation’s employers added 120,000 jobs.
articles.abstract: In the midst of global economic turmoil, the American unemployment rate unexpectedly dropped last month to 8.6 percent, and the nation’s employers added 120,000 jobs.
articles.lead_paragraph: Somehow the American economy appears to be getting better, even as the rest of the world is looking worse.
